title: Constants (Values That Never Change)
simplifierConcept:
Some values should NEVER change:

üåç Earth's gravity: 9.8 m/s¬≤
ü•ß Pi: 3.14159...
üíØ Max score: 100
üìÖ Days in week: 7

VARIABLE = Can change:
int score = 0;
score = 10;  // ‚úÖ Allowed
score = 20;  // ‚úÖ Allowed

CONSTANT = Cannot change:
const int MAX_SCORE = 100;
MAX_SCORE = 200;  // ‚ùå ERROR! Can't change constant

Why use constants?
‚úÖ Prevents accidental changes
‚úÖ Makes code more readable
‚úÖ Easy to update in one place
‚úÖ Compiler optimizes them

Think: const = A locked box that can't be changed!

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: const keyword makes variable unchangeable. Must assign value immediately. Type required (int, double, string, etc.). Use ALL_CAPS naming convention.
Convention: Constants use ALL_CAPS with UNDERSCORES. Makes them easy to spot in code. const int MAX_SCORE = 100; Not required, but strong convention.
Value must be known at compile time. Can't use variable: const int x = 5; const int y = x; is OK. But can't use method results or user input!
const = compile-time, can't change ever. readonly = runtime, can set in constructor once. const is stricter. readonly covered in OOP later.

challenge.instructions:
Create a currency converter with constants!

1. Define constants:
   - USD_TO_EUR = 0.85
   - USD_TO_GBP = 0.73
   - USD_TO_JPY = 110.0
   - APP_NAME = "Currency Converter"
   - VERSION = "1.0"

2. Display app name and version
3. Ask user for USD amount
4. Convert to all three currencies
5. Display all conversions

Example:
Enter USD: 100
100 USD = 85 EUR
100 USD = 73 GBP
100 USD = 11000 JPY
challenge.hint: Use const for values that never change. ALL_CAPS naming. Multiply USD amount by each conversion rate constant. Display with string interpolation.
commonStickingPoints: Trying to change constant: const int X = 5; X = 10; ERROR! Constants are locked forever. Use regular variable if you need to change it.
Forgetting to initialize: const int X; ERROR! Must assign value immediately: const int X = 5; Can't assign later like variables.
Using wrong naming: const int maxScore = 100; works but bad style. Use const int MAX_SCORE = 100; for readability.
Runtime values: const int x = int.Parse(input); ERROR! Constant value must be known at compile time. Can't use user input or method calls that run later.
